title: Privilege Escalation via Keybase Helper
vulnerability_information_html:
A privilege escalation vulnerability exists within the KeybaseHelper application available when installing the Keybase Desktop Application on MacOS.

The issue is exposed via a LaunchDaemon plist which is installed within /Library/LaunchDaemons/keybase.Helper.plist. This file is responsible for launching /Library/PrivilegedHelperTools/keybase.Helper for the registered mach port keybase.Helper.

If we take the source code located at https://github.com/keybase/client/blob/master/osx/Helper/KBHelper.m, we can see a number of exposed "methods" via an XPC connection, including:

  • remove - Ability to remove any file on the filesystem as the root user
  • move - Ability to move any file on the filesystem as the root user
  • createDirectory - Ability to create a directory as the root user, and provide attributes such as the owner UID/GID and permissions
  • addToPath - Add applications to the /usr/local/bin directory
  • kextInstall - Add and start kext

Interacting with the helper via XPC takes place via the MPMessagePack framework, which is available from https://github.com/gabriel/MPMessagePack/blob/master/XPC/MPXPCClient.m.

If we craft a very simple POC, we can see that it is trivial to place files within dangerous locations:

    NSError *error;
    MPXPCClient *client = [[MPXPCClient alloc] initWithServiceName:@"keybase.Helper" privileged:true];
    [client connect:&error];

    // Moves any file from "source" to "destination" as the root user
    [client sendRequest:@"move" params:@[@{@"source":@"/tmp/src", @"destination":@"/Library/dst"}] completion: ^(NSError *error, id value) {
        NSLog(@"WORKS");
    }];

It does appear than an effort has been made to avoid executing arbitrary applications by the helper, for example, we can see the following comments within the "" method:

    // Make sure the passed-in redirector binary points to a proper binary
    // signed by Keybase, we don't want this to be able to run arbitrary code
    // as root.

This doesn't stop us from elevating privileges however, for example, we can simply use the 'move' method to copy any file (or overwrite any file). As a simple example, below we can see a simple operation moving a plist file into /Library/LaunchDaemons/com.xpnsec.test.plist:

    [client sendRequest:@"move" params:@[@{@"source":@"/tmp/elevate.plist", @"destination":@"/Library/LaunchDaemons/com.xpnsec.test.plist"}] completion: ^(NSError *error, id value) {
        NSLog(@"WORKS");
    }];

On reboot, we see that our service is installed and executed as the root user.

Alternatively, we can simply copy our malicious payload using the above method to /Library/PrivilegedHelperTools/keybase.Helper and spawn via our XPC call.

Impact

The impact would be elevation of privileges from any user with permission to access the keybase.Helper XPC service (which is currently all users) to the root user on macOS.

activities.message: Thanks for the report, we'll investigate ASAP
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for the report, we'll investigate ASAP

activities.message: Repro'ed on my laptop
activities.markdown_message: Repro'ed on my laptop

activities.message:
Hey,

Just received a security update for KeyBase on MacOS. Looking at GitHub, there appear to have been security updates in the above affected file (https://github.com/keybase/client/blob/3ca00128473306307df15e8a8448636fb3c765d8/osx/Helper/KBHelper.m). 

I've not had chance to check the new version, however it appears that code signing verification has been added for calls into the XPC service. Is this implemented to mitigate the above?

Thanks
Adam
activities.markdown_message:
Hey,

Just received a security update for KeyBase on MacOS. Looking at GitHub, there appear to have been security updates in the above affected file (https://github.com/keybase/client/blob/3ca00128473306307df15e8a8448636fb3c765d8/osx/Helper/KBHelper.m).

I've not had chance to check the new version, however it appears that code signing verification has been added for calls into the XPC service. Is this implemented to mitigate the above?

Thanks
Adam

activities.message: Hi Adam, Yes, we indeed rolled out a patch yesterday. Can you confirm that it's fixed? Thank you, Max
activities.markdown_message: Hi Adam, Yes, we indeed rolled out a patch yesterday. Can you confirm that it's fixed? Thank you, Max

activities.message:
Ah awesome! I've re-run the tests above, and now an error is returned within the callback from the [client sendRequest] method, so this fix looks good to me.

Nice work with the quick turnaround.

Thanks
Adam
activities.markdown_message:
Ah awesome! I've re-run the tests above, and now an error is returned within the callback from the [client sendRequest] method, so this fix looks good to me.

Nice work with the quick turnaround.

Thanks
Adam

activities.message: Great research, great report. Thank you very much for your contribution.
activities.markdown_message: Great research, great report. Thank you very much for your contribution.

activities.message: Nice, thanks for the bounty. I try and share any of my findings on my blog (https://blog.xpnsec.com), do you have any objection to me writing this up now it has been fixed?
activities.markdown_message: Nice, thanks for the bounty. I try and share any of my findings on my blog (https://blog.xpnsec.com), do you have any objection to me writing this up now it has been fixed?

activities.message: Hi, do you mind holding off for several release cycles?  Not everyone upgrades right away, and we want to give people plenty of time to upgrade before we disclose the issue.  Thank you.
activities.markdown_message: Hi, do you mind holding off for several release cycles? Not everyone upgrades right away, and we want to give people plenty of time to upgrade before we disclose the issue. Thank you.

activities.message: No problem, I'll hold off disclosing until the patch has been distributed. Thanks.
activities.markdown_message: No problem, I'll hold off disclosing until the patch has been distributed. Thanks.

activities.message: Thanks so much for understanding and bearing with us.  BTW, our team was discussing it internally, and we decided that the recommend $2,500 bounty was insufficient, given the quality of the research and the quality of our interaction. So we all decided to double it.  Thanks again!
activities.markdown_message: Thanks so much for understanding and bearing with us. So we all decided to double it. Thanks again!

activities.message: OK that's awesome, thanks Keybase!
activities.markdown_message: OK that's awesome, thanks Keybase!

activities.message: Hey, How do we feel about disclosing this now, do you think enough time has passed for updates to have been distributed? Thanks.
activities.markdown_message: Hey, How do we feel about disclosing this now, do you think enough time has passed for updates to have been distributed? Thanks.

activities.message: Haven't forgotten.  Let's wait a couple more release cycles. How is Dec 3 for you? Many thanks!
activities.markdown_message: Haven't forgotten. Let's wait a couple more release cycles. How is Dec 3 for you? Many thanks!

activities.message: Sounds good to me :)
activities.markdown_message: Sounds good to me :)

activities.message: Running a few days behind. We just got mailers out last week telling stranded users (those whose updaters seem to have failed) to upgrade. This week, we'll disable the affected versions on the server, and then disclose hopefully by the end of the week. Thanks.
activities.markdown_message: Running a few days behind. We just got mailers out last week telling stranded users (those whose updaters seem to have failed) to upgrade. This week, we'll disable the affected versions on the server, and then disclose hopefully by the end of the week. Thanks.

activities.message: No worries, happy to wait until everything is good your side.
activities.markdown_message: No worries, happy to wait until everything is good your side.

activities.message: Hi quick update! We've enabled shutdown warnings on all of our old apps, sent out emails, and also now sending out keybase messages to all users running old apps.  People don't like to upgrade, it turns out!  Hopefully Friday, or maybe Monday, we'll brick the old apps, and then that'll force people to uninstall them or install over them.  Sorry to be behind, we're working diligently to get there. Thank you!
activities.markdown_message: Hi quick update! We've enabled shutdown warnings on all of our old apps, sent out emails, and also now sending out keybase messages to all users running old apps. People don't like to upgrade, it turns out! Hopefully Friday, or maybe Monday, we'll brick the old apps, and then that'll force people to uninstall them or install over them. Sorry to be behind, we're working diligently to get there. Thank you!

How are you getting on with those final users?

activities.message: We're doing one last release this week before the holidays, and will post the security advisory afterwards. Thank you.
